content: The Act titled "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2016" defines terms like "improper payment" and "questionable transaction." It also explains "strategic sourcing" as a way to analyze and modify spending patterns to improve performance. The Act aims to expand the use of data analytics. The Act "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2016" mandates the development of a strategy to expand data analytics in managing government purchase and travel charge card programs. This strategy aims to identify questionable transactions, recover improper payments, and find opportunities for agencies to improve their spending patterns. The Act mandates the development of a strategy to expand data analytics in managing government purchase and travel charge card programs, including identifying opportunities for streamlining processes and reducing costs, developing metrics for high-risk activities, and creating a library of analytics tools for Federal agencies to use. SEC. 4. GUIDANCE ON IMPROVING INFORMATION SHARING TO CURB IMPROPER PAYMENTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant agencies, will issue guidance on improving information sharing among government agencies to curb improper payments. This guidance will require federal agencies to identify high-risk activities, communicate this information to appropriate management levels, and review reports from charge card-issuing banks on questionable transaction activity. The Director will issue guidance on improving information sharing among government agencies to curb improper payments, requiring federal agencies to identify high-risk activities and share information on potential questionable transactions and fraud schemes. This guidance will also include requirements for reporting on card transactions, delinquency reports, and suspicious activities. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY CHARGE CARD DATA MANAGEMENT GROUP. Establishment of a purchase and travel charge card data management group by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop and share best practices for charge card-issuing banks, review of accounts payable information, and identifying strategic sourcing opportunities. The purchase and travel charge card data management group, established by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will meet regularly for three years to develop best practices and include relevant agencies as determined by the co-chairs. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The General Services Administration and Federal agencies must submit reports to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including metrics for reducing improper payments and improving card-based payment utilization. The Office of Management and Budget will also submit a report to Congress. The Administrator of General Services will submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment, identifying additional savings opportunities for government agencies under the Federal charge card programs. This report may be combined with the report required by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
